content: The NLRA, as amended, aims to improve the bargaining power of workers in the private sector by addressing the inequality of bargaining power between employees and employers. It is declared as the policy of the United States to eliminate obstacles to the free flow of commerce and mitigate business depressions caused by wage rate depressions and unstable working conditions. The NLRA aims to eliminate obstructions to commerce and promote collective bargaining. It gives workers the right to join or form a union, bargain collectively, and protects against unfair labor practices. Employers must bargain in good faith with a union chosen by the majority of employees. The NLRA requires employers to bargain in good faith with a union chosen by the majority of employees and defines certain activities as unfair labor practices. It does not apply to certain industries or exclude unauthorized workers from engaging in union activities. The NLRB, an independent federal agency, administers and enforces the NLRA. The NLRB is an independent federal agency that enforces the NLRA and consists of a five-member board and a General Counsel. The board resolves objections to secret ballot elections, decides on bargaining unit composition, and hears appeals of unfair labor practices. The General Counsel's office conducts secret ballot elections, investigates unfair labor practice complaints, and supervises regional offices. Bargaining units are groups of employees represented by a union based on a "community of interest." A bargaining unit is determined based on a "community of interest" of employees with similar interests in wages, hours, and working conditions. It may include employees of one employer, establishment, or occupation. Professional and nonprofessional employees can be in the same unit if the majority of professionals agree. Guards cannot be in the same unit as other employees. The appropriate bargaining unit can be agreed upon by the union and employer or settled by the NLRB. In August 2011, the NLRB reviewed a case where CNAs at a healthcare center in Mobile, AL, petitioned to be represented by the USW. The Regional Director deemed the CNAs as an appropriate bargaining unit, but the employer disputed this decision. The Director found the petitioned-for unit of CNAs to be an appropriate bargaining unit at a healthcare center. The employer disagreed and argued that the bargaining unit should include all nonprofessional service and maintenance employees. The CNAs assist residents with daily tasks, wear nursing uniforms, are supervised by licensed practical nurses, and are part of the nursing department. The CNAs at the healthcare center wear nursing uniforms, are supervised by licensed practical nurses, and work in three eight-hour shifts. They must maintain certification from the state of Alabama. The employer argued that other employees like resident activity assistants, a staffing coordinator, a maintenance assistant, a medical records clerk, and cooks should be included in the bargaining unit. The board voted in favor of the CNAs, determining that their petitioned-for bargaining unit was approved. The CNAs have specific work schedules, wear nursing uniforms, and are supervised by licensed practical nurses. Other employees with similar educational requirements are not part of the nursing department and do not work the same shifts. The board approved the CNAs' petitioned-for bargaining unit, citing their distinct training, certification, supervision, uniforms, pay rates, work assignments, shifts, and work areas. They did not share an overwhelming community of interest with other service and maintenance employees.
